direction.raw_text: And I don't have to guess about it. EXT. WOODS - LATER Quoyle RUNNING, huffing, through a bog with every color of berries imaginable. Around another bend in the path. Stops. Hands on his knees. Listens.   Nothing.   Shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! More nothing. He trudges back the way he came.              Peeks around a bend to see... ...Bunny is teaching Berry to pick gooseberries. This time, the learning has started. They are being very careful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you pick enough, we can sell 'em for a thousand dollars. And give it to Aunt Agnis to make up for those Staties who didn't pay h...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then don't. Slow us. Down. Quoyle SLAPS his hands across his mouth.         Sorry!     He tiptoes off. Rounds a bend. Walking faster now... Around another bend. And stops.         Hold on his face.      REVERSE ANGLE to take his view of... ...Petal, kneeling in a flimsy sundress, picking berries. Barefoot, her skirt hiked up, stained with berry juice. And when she turns to him... ...she is still Petal. Her face is beautiful, and filled with tender desire. She looks at him the way he has always dreamed she would. He goes to... ...kneel beside her.       Touch her waist.    And now she is... ...another woman. His hand is on Wavey's waist, and it comes slowly away. But her eyes are locked to his. Making her choice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look.    I like you. Even in kindness, he can smell rejection.          He starts to back away, but she takes his hand. Holds it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want us.     To be friends, okay? He nods, dumbly.     Of course.     Okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And friends. Need.       To understand each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. Believe m...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My husband drowned.      Herry was... Hard for her.   He quiets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was two months old. And Herold took the boat out. Overnight. To fish for haddock. Do you understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I liked.     Haddock. Silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's four years. She stares in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And it's yesterday. No smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, did I blow it.     Or can you still be my friend? A beat. Quoyle nods, sure. I'll be your friend. But what she sees is a lifetime of being Quoyle washing past his eyes. It makes her murmur...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?    What are you thinking? And from his heart...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm thinking I'm sorry.     For everything. He stands up.   HEAR him stumble off.     HOLD on her. EXT. GREEN HILLSIDE - DAY A grassy place above an empty sea.      The rest of the world far away. Two figures climb the gentle hill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How're you doin' with the Tall and Quiet Woman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cindy Crawford and me is doin' fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I meant Wavey Prowse. Oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My dad used to say there's four women in every man's life. The Stouthearted Woman...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, that'd be Agnis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...the Maid in the Meadow...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bunny I guess. Weavin' a daisy-chain necklace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...the Tall and Quiet Woman...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. She does have that posture goin'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and the Demon Lover. On this. Quoyle's smile fades. He looks away. They've reached a fence where blunt pickets enclose crosses and wooden markers, many fallen on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me dad said that. Billy finds the right marker. Sets his satchel onto the grass. Kneels. His old fingers clear debris from painted words: W. PRETTY. 1897 - 1944. THROUGH THE GREAT STORMS OF LIFE, HE DID HIS BEST. GOD GRANT HIM ETERNAL REST.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's me poor father.     Thirteen I was when he died. He hears the thread of feeling in his simple words. And says no more. Withdraws two cans of paint from his bag. One white, one black. Two brushes. Lays them out carefully, for this task is sacred.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Every time I wonder.     Is this the last coat? Pries the lid off the tin of black.     And when he sees Quoyle's eyes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, there's no one else to do it, y'see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is now. An easy smile.   Stating the obvious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's me. The old man's face just stops.     The eyes sharpen.   Into a question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, you said. There's no one else. As if that were enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey. If you wanna rest next to him. I'll paint yours at the same time. No extra trouble. Billy stares at him.     Stares at him.   Clears his throat, gruffly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then better get Alvin Yark. T'build yer a real boat. So yer'll be around. EXT. GREEN HOUSE - DAY Quoyle exits the house, pulling on his jacket, and... ...stops. Something laid across his threshold. A long piece of TWINE has been placed there. KNOTS tied evenly along its length. He glances back up to the second floor, thinking Bunny. Looks at the thing again. Neat work. Odd. Slips it in his pocket. EXT. CLIFFSIDE - DAY Quoyle now making his way down a steep primitive trail through lush vegetation. The green house is far above him. The shimmering bay now just below. This way down as treacherous as it is wondrous, and Quoyle SLIPS in the tangle and wet, half-slides through wild angelica stalks and patches of dogberry, suddenly... ...LOSING his balance, TUMBLING roughly down a stretch, rolling, grasping a spruce trunk. Pulling himself to his feet, he hears... RUSTLING. Looks up, just as... ...a WHITE DOG appears through the bushes. Red eyes. Lips curled back. A frozen second of mutual indecision, and Quoyle... ...SCREAMS and falls on his butt.     The dog... ...TAKES OFF, bounding down a path we hadn't noticed. Toward an upright SILHOUETTE. Who steps into sun just long enough to become... ...a MAN, grizzled and scrawny and quick.      Gone in a flash.   Like a skinny ghost. And there, on his butt... ...Quoyle laughs softly.     How 'bout that?   Murmurs...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Attaway, girl. You're smarter'n all of us. As he climbs to his feet, he sees the rocky beach just below. Squints, as if at something that doesn't belong. We see it now... ...a SUITCASE, washed up onto a tangle of rocks, just offshore. ANGLE...Quoyle wading into the water. Up to his knees, slips, sinks to his waist. Stays upright. Snatches the suitcase from its perch. Brings it back to shore, holding it high. Already, he is making the face of someone smelling something he'd rather not. He sets it down. The face is worse.     His curiosity running the show, he unhooks the latch... ...and stops. Because he's staring inside. Suddenly, he SCREAMS and FLAILS back, his leg STRIKING the case, and out tumbles onto the wet ground... ...the head.   Of Bayonet Melville. INT. SKIPPER WILL'S DINER - NIGHT Three guys. Three beers. Five squidburgers (Quoyle likes his backups ready and waiting).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Y'know none a that impresses Jack Buggit. He's not one fer blatant ambition. Quoyle thinks better of his answer.    Chomps a bite instead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even if you don't recognize 'Human Head Packed in Satchel' as the most compelling piece ever to appear in...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even if. ...takes his hand from his greasy burger.    Scratches his crotch below the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A triple increase in ad revenue. Does get. The man's attention. And winks at the silent hero.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Weren't even double if yer figger it right. (to Quoyle) Point is. A real reporter woulda named the obvious suspect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More obvious. Than the wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yer aunt, ya thick Statie lardface dumbass! Quoyle.   And Nutbeem.   Just look at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets stiffed by the guy, after basin' her new shop on that revenue. And she ain't one ta fool with. Capable a anything, that woman!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, where's the wife? Agnis kill her too?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, where's this week's shipping news? Or you gonna rest on yer Crisco-coated laurels. Quoyle viciously BITES into his squidburger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uh-oh. The way he's chewin', he ain't a fat boy t'be trifled with!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His piece.     Is about oil tankers. Card blinks.   Looks at Quoyle with, dare we say, new respect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hope fer ya yet. Now that's news, the McGonigle oil field. Petrodollars, a golden flood a jobs. That's th'future a this god-forsaken ice rock. Civilization! Scratches his crotch savagely.      To honor civilization.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why those with half a brain already put our money where our mouths is! Puts his squidburger.    Where his mouth is.    Nutbeem clarifies for Quoyle...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two shares. Of Mobil. INT. WAVEY'S HOUSE - NIGHT ANGLE...brightly lit kitchen. Bunny sits at the little table, a large mixing bowl filled with popcorn before her, little Herry at her side. They are watching Freakazoid on a tiny TV. Bunny shovels in a mouthful of popcorn. Then makes a sage, if unintelligible, comment about the show to Herry. Still chewing, she takes another huge handful of popcorn... ...Herry opens his mouth like a baby bird. Bunny stuffs the snack in. It's a stare-and-chew, side by side. Just alike. ANGLE...cozy parlor. Quoyle sits in a Barca-lounger with a huge bowl of chips in his lap. He is watching hockey on a modest TV, the action is fierce. Stuffs his mouth full of chips, yet somehow manages to say...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...so there they were, this goofy old codger and his dog, big as life. PULL BACK to see Wavey now. Curled on the sofa, under a lap robe. She is knitting something in a heavy oxblood-colored wool. He watches her work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That'd be old Nolan. He's actually your uncle, last of the crazy Quoyles. I should have realized. Keeps her eyes on her work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sad, really. Lives like a hermit in a run-down shack. No one to look after h...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here I was worried about Bunny night and day, and there's absolutely nothing wrong with her. A silence.   Which makes him uneasy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her only problem is her dad worries too mu...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a loving and wonderful father. You're not the problem. She meant to reassure him.    Instead...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So what is th...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice to see you. Looks up with smoky eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...after all this time. Oh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well. I've been workin' longer hours. So Dennis and Beety were kind enough to bring Bunny to the daycare. Fed her a lotta meals, too. They're real friends. Quoyle's smile tries to sell the innocence of his absence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you forgot. That I'm your friend, too. No smile from her. She wants him to know she was hurt.           He shakes his head, serious now. No, I didn't forget.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want another sandwich?    There's roast pork. He holds up what's left of his four-decker.          This is plenty.   Takes a huge bite to show how much he likes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said.    You'd read me your article. He did, he nods.     But just now he's scared to. And so she smiles. Which traps him.     He pulls out a single sheet of paper. Clears his throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody Hangs a Picture of an Oil Tanker. That's the header. She nods. Likes that. He gestures, go back to your knitting.             So she smiles, slyly. And commences to knit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a 1904 photo hung in the library. Eight schooners heading out to fishing grounds, sails spread it like white wings. Beautiful. Beyond compare. This means something to him.       Hear it in his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More common today is the low black profile of oil tankers. Like the ruptured Golden Goose, which last week bled 14,000 tons of crude onto seabirds, fish and boats at Cape Despond. He stops.    As if revisiting that little thought in his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There will be more and more tankers. They will grow old and corroded, and their tanks will split. They have already done to fishing. What their spill has done to fish. He sneaks a glance.       She has never looked up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody hangs a picture of an oil tanker. On their wall. Silence.    A full one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well.     Whatcha think? She reflects.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think when Card sees it, he'll split a gut. I think he'll sit up nights thinking of cheap shots to pay you back. I think he'll never stop until you're fired. Quoyle keeps nodding at each point.          Yep.   Yep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think I haven't been so proud. Of a friend. Since I don't know when. Quoyle's heart explodes in his chest.          And shines in his eyes. There is a long silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe another sandwich. There's roast pork. He swallows.    He just doesn't want to cry from happiness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, sure. INT. GAMMY BIRD - DAY CLOSE on Card. Who is RIPPING the single page in half. Then again. And again. And again. See Quoyle now, standing at the desk like a statue. Billy and Nutbeem at their stations, watching as Card... ...flutters the pieces down onto his desk.       Like falling snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I'll run it. Just easier t'copy edit. When yer can move th'pieces around. A hush.    A frozen tableau in this room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Run it.   Like I wrote it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How does this suit yer, Quoyle? I'll do my job. You do yers, which means a four-vehicle pile-up south a Killick-Claw. And don't ferget the camera. He slides the battered camera across the desk. They glare at each other a full beat. Card belches, softly. Quoyle takes the camera, heads for the door...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I fergot somethin'. Quoyle turns.    Card doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You pinko Greepeace sack a quivering pigfat. Thinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did I leave out moosebutt-ugly? (nods to himself) You may go. HOLD on him.    Making a neat little pile of the torn pieces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like I wrote it. SLAMM! Across the room, Nutbeem stands.        Takes his cigarettes. Passing Card's desk, on the way out...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tough love. Impressive. SLAMM!    Card shoots Billy a challenging look.     You got something to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you get him fired. Do you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I can watch him beat yer to jelly. Just turns around.     Flicks ON his computer.   Back to work. EXT. GREEN HOUSE - TWILIGHT Bunny jumping out of the wagon, running to the house.      As Quoyle locks his car...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why'd you leave the house open? He looks up.   She is pushing the front door with one finger.     It swings OPEN.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I keep the necklace? ...and lifts a long piece of TWINE. There are KNOTS neatly tied along its length. Quoyle stares. Stares.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sweetie.     Come sit in the car. INT. FRONT HALLWAY - TWILIGHT Quoyle climbing the stairs in fading light. He carries a tire iron. Stops midway. Listens to the silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! Up, up, to the top.     Looking down the empty hall to see... ...knotted twine.     At every door. INT. GAMMY BIRD - EARLY MORNING Quoyle enters, haggard and distracted. The place is lit, but empty. A toilet FLUSHES. From the loo, appears...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S'tell me.     Yer fancy it? Nodding toward something behind Quoyle. Turning, we see that hanging over Card's desk is an oversized framed photo of: QUIET EYE - WORLD'S LARGEST OIL TANKER. Quoyle stares blankly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Like I said.    Nobody hangs those. Card just goes to the fresh stack of newspapers on his desk.       Hands one toward Quoyle...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yer column's front page stuff. Only now, it's more like a caption, is all. A photo of the same tanker.       That hangs on Card's wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More than 3000 tankers proudly ride the world's seas. Even the biggest take advantage of Newfoundland's deep- water ports and refineries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spelled everthin' perfect.     So as not t'embarrass yer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oil and Newfoundland go together like ham and eggs, and like ham and eggs they'll nourish us in the coming years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even put yer name on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's all hang a picture of an oil tanker. On our wall. Stares at the paper.     In his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Man a yer principles. I unnerstan' resignation is th'only honorable course. Quoyle looks up.     Card flinches back.    But all that comes is...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can a man resign.    To nobody? Drops the paper on the floor.       Steps on it, on his way toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If yer off to see Jack Buggit, yer'll hafta swim some. Quoyle turns back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yer can whine an' beg t'him.     But I runs his paper, every inch of it, every dirty time-eatin' job which he would have t'do without me. A wink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An' if yer think he's gonna choose you over fishin'...yer not as smart as even you look! The cackle of the guy holding the straight flush.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me an' Jack. Has a sym-bi-otic relationship. Yer can look that up. Quoyle puts his hand on the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know the word, Card. It means you two deserve each other. Out the door.   It closes behind him.    Card alone, crosses his arms in glee...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! HOLD on Card.   DISSOLVE TO... INT. GAMMY BIRD - DAY CLOSE on a box of assorted doughnuts. Two dozen. A hand reaches down toward a raspberry swirl, thinks better of it, moves thoughtfully along the selection to pluck a maple glaze, and bring it to... ...Quoyle's mouth. The box rests beside the cardboard carton into which Quoyle is packing his things. Nutbeem sits on the edge of the desk, nibbling a cruller. Billy is bringing three mugs of coffee. Looks like a going-away party. Through the glass of the only private office... ...Jack Buggit is talking. Card is not. Card stands now, strides to the door, flings it OPEN. Nutbeem taps Quoyle's shoulder with his pastry. They look to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So.    This is what Jack and I think. He's looking straight in Quoyle's eyes.     Defiant as ever.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We wanna run Quoyle's oil spill piece b'cause controversy sells papers and papers sells ads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sounds reasonable to me. Lives to needle this guy.     Card keeps his laser gaze on Quoyle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And we're gonna let Quoyle have his head on these columns, up to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: words. So he'll get his confidence up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, let's not go overboard.    He's rather green doncha thi...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we wanna expand his responsi- bilities to boat crashes. There's maybe four a week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He'll need a raise. And need to be represented in the negotia...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And.   The oil tanker picture.   Stays! Nutbeem's eyes WIDEN. He mimes catching an arrow shot through his chest. Falls OFF the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All that clear? Quoyle looks him in the eyes.     Starts putting his things back in his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One more thing... Hear the SLAMM!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack's gone fishing? EXT. OMALOOR BAY - DAY The sky threatens black. Quoyle picks his way across the rocks to his ungainly, much-maligned boat, as it bobs against the weathered dock. He crouches, and as he begins to untie it, his gaze drifts out toward the nearby point, and... ...something catches his eye. A boulder in the shape of a great dog. And as he stares, there is something below it. Something in a cove protected from intrusion by a jagged ring of menacing rocks... ...it is a MAN in a yellow suit. His head under the surface as if looking for fish. Arms and legs spread out like a starfish, the body slides in and out of a small cave. Tugged by the sea like a top on a string. Quoyle stares in frozen shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Headline. Reporter Becomes Magnet For Dead Men. No way in past the pounding surf, the savage rocks.    So Quoyle turns sharply. Squints across the bay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What was my panic? He was already dead. Maybe I thought, in some dim way... CLIMBS into his boat, TURNS the engine over.    KICKS it in overdrive toward the town across the bay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...if it wasn't too late for him. It wouldn't be for Petal. STREAKING out, toward the black sky.    Racing to open sea where the chop INCREASES drastically. Closer.     Closer...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once I was past the shelter of the lee shore, and into the real wind. I realized my mistake. ...clear of the point's protection, the wind ROCKS the tiny craft, swells coming BROADSIDE. The boat RISES, then DROPS with cruel speed. Quoyle tries to swing the boat around, the propeller RACES, the bow PITCHES violently, SLAMMING down, the stern SWAMPED, the hull filling, swerving broadside just as the oncoming sea HITS with all its force, and the little boat... ...rolls OVER, Quoyle suddenly FLYING under water, limbs flailing in all directions...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Headline.    Reporter Becomes Anchor Man. INTERCUT...Quoyle's dad FLINGING him into the public pool, the youngster SINKING like an anvil in a profusion of bubbles, and CUT... BACK to Quoyle, struggling madly somehow to the surface, THRASHING toward the overturned boat, GRASPING the stilled propeller shaft, which causes the bow to lift, the next wave turning the boat upright, FILLING it with water, and it SINKS forever, as Quoyle... ...TUMBLES once more beneath the surface, watching the boat DISAPPEAR into darkness below him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stupid. Stupid to drown with Bunny so young. No life jacket, no floating oar. No sense. Back to the surface, GASPING for air. And then, daintily rowing a small boat, unaffected by the waves, her filmy dress rippling in light breeze...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, it floats.     Just like you. Is the lilting smile cruel?   Or only the irony that conveys intimacy, even affection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's filled with fat. And VANISHES. In her place, bobs a red BOX. A plastic beer cooler. He LUNGES for it, GRIPPING the handles, resting his chest on its top. The waves RISE, mountainous now, and he rises and falls with them. He has been swept a mile from the nearest shore. INTERCUT...a winch pulling part of the Geo, streaming mud, from swiftly flowing water. Police and bystanders gathered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I wondered. Am I going where she's gone? BACK to the bay. A barely-conscious Quoyle still clings somehow to the plastic cooler. But hours have passed. Light is fading.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...and will I see her? He turns. And there she is. Beaming at him from the bow of her little rowboat, a smile ambiguous in the growing dusk. It could be love. From behind her a light GLOWS, giving Petal the aspect of an angel. She drops a wink.   FADES away.    And the light becomes... ...the BEAM from a fishing boat. Quoyle squints his swollen eyes, as strong hands WRENCH him from his box. From the sea. A voice warbles, distorted by wind and Quoyle's diminished consciousness...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jesus Cockadoodle Christ!     I knowed somebody was out here. Quoyle's teeth are chattering so hard, his body shivering so painfully, Buggit hauls him over the rail and lays him down on a wriggling mound of fish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank god fer yer figure, me old son. A thin man woulda froze. Quoyle burrows into the fish, like nestling in a down comforter. Jack covers him with a heavy tarp. Crouches down close...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good.   Yer lost th'boat. INT. BEDROOM - LATE NIGHT Dim light. Quoyle stirs beneath the billowing down coverlet.   His eyes flutter. Open. Where...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right. You're in heaven. His head SNAPS around. She's sitting just beside the bed in half- shadow. Her oxblood knitting across her lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually.    It's just my bed. Now he sees the cigarette.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Actually, it's not. I just wanted to see your eyes bug out like that. Now he sees the smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't smoke. His voice was a croak. So he CLEARS his throat with a massive and disgusting effort. It is gross and funny, and she smiles again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only when I'm worried.      I don't worry much. He rolls over, to see her better.      They are very close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't have to, I'm all right. I'm in heaven.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not worried.    About you. Oh.   As he draws a breath to ask...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're in the boys' room at Jack's house. Wonder how long since Dennis slept here. She glances to the nightstand. Beneath the dim lamp.       A picture of Jack and blond son Jesson. Guess what they're doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Buggit called, knew Bunny was still with me. The kids are camped out in the parlor. A beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice.   You sittin' up with me. A longer one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S'okay. Someday you'll do somethin' nice for me. He nods.   He will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who you worried ab...
direction.name: direction
